channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Panel Orders Release of Memo in Targeted Killing of Awlaki
item.description: The classified document provided the legal justification for the killing of Anwar al-Awlaki, an American citizen who had joined Al Qaeda and died in a drone strike in Yemen.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: The Lede: Portuguese Drone Program Off to Nonflying Start
item.description: The Portuguese Navy’s fledgling drone program attracted international attention last week because of footage of the failed maiden voyage of a new reconnaissance craft.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Ethnic Groups Targeted in South Sudan Killings
item.description: In a report, the United Nations confirmed that rebel forces killed hundreds of civilians based on their ethnic origins and nationality.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: Syria Announces a June Presidential Election
item.description: The election, which will almost certainly award Bashar al-Assad a new term, was criticized by the opposition and the United Nations.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 21
item.description: HTC, a company based in Taiwan, unveiled new smartphones at a function in New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Artists performing during a launch of new smartphones by HTC, a Taiwanese company, at a function in New Delhi.

item.title: Russian Foreign Minister Accuses Kiev of Flouting Ukraine Accord
item.description: With Vice President Joseph R. Biden in Kiev on Monday, comments from Russia’s foreign minister suggested that Moscow may be preparing groundwork for a military intervention.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: A pro-Russia activist hung a flag on the regional administration building seized by separatists as armed men guarded a building in Slovyansk.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China to Allow the Blind to Take College Entrance Exams
item.description: The Education Ministry’s decision to allow blind people to take the regular “gaokao,” or university entrance examinations, has been welcomed by the blind and their advocates.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Lin Jinsheng, 46, a blind masseur who wants to study law, plans to take the university entrance examination in June under the Education Ministry's new policy.

item.title: Rockets From Gaza Draw Israeli Airstrikes
item.description: The exchange of fire between Palestinian militants and Israeli forces came as an April 29 deadline for peace talks drew near.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: An Israeli boy looks at shrapnel at a parking lot in the Israeli border town of Sderot.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Assault by City Management Officers Triggers Clash
item.description: Urban enforcement officers clashed Saturday with residents in a town in the eastern province of Zhejiang, the latest in a long series of violent interactions between the officers and street peddlers and bystanders.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Letter From Europe: Geopolitics, France and a Ship Order
item.description: For workers at a French shipyard building two Russian military ships, what matters above all are the jobs, not the politics of the Ukraine standoff.
item.dc:creator: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Court Orders Seizure of Japanese Vessel
item.description: The ship, the Baosteel Emotion, is a bulk carrier owned by Mitsui O.S.K. Lines, which the court said had failed to pay compensation resulting from a 1930s contractual obligation.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga said the Japanese government is "gravely concerned."

item.title: India Ink: Mumbai’s Business Community Tries New Enterprise: Politics
item.description: Members of the white-collar elite who have shunned participating in past campaigns are now motivated to stump for Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party.
item.dc:creator: By MANSI CHOKSI
item.media:description: Arvind Sawant, center, the Shiv Sena candidate from South Mumbai, interacting with morning walkers at Priyadarshini park in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Southern Pays U.S. Fine Over Monkey Cargo
item.description: The state-owned carrier paid a fine of $11,600 levied by the United States Department of Agriculture for violating the Animal Welfare Act in transporting over a thousand macaques to Chicago without proper registration.
item.category: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: Chinese Southern Airlines had long been the target of animal welfare advocates for its role in transporting primates to laboratories in the United States and other countries.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Ray of Literary Hope on Italian TV
item.description: In recent decades television has done major cultural damage, but it may be our best tool for change.
item.dc:creator: By RAFFAELLA SILVESTRI

item.title: In Hong Kong, Some Bankers Back an ‘Occupy’ Movement
item.description: Several dozen members of Hong Kong’s financial class hope more of their number will join Occupy Central, which plans protests demanding unfettered elections.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: More Crew Members Detained in Korean Ferry Investigation
item.description: Three of the ship’s mates and a chief engineer aboard the sunken ferry were detained on Monday, as divers continued to search for the missing.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Prominent Scientist Welcomes Soil Pollution Report
item.description: A leading Chinese scientist welcomed the release of a government report on contaminants in soil, a first in the country, but questioned why it had been done in such an understated manner.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Chimneys from a state-owned lead smelter and foundry alongside agricultural fields in Anhui Province. The sign warns against constructing residential buildings within 800 meters.

item.title: Afghan Couple Find Idyllic Hide-Out in Mountains, but Not for Long
item.description: Mohammad Ali and Zakia, running from her family and the police, were welcomed into the home of distant relatives until their location was revealed.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: April 21
item.description: A roundup of local election-related news for Monday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Supporters of Bharatiya Janata Party campaigning atop fishing boats on the shores of Chennai, Tamil Nadu, on Thursday.

item.title: Militants Kill Soldiers in Algeria
item.description: Qaeda-affiliated fighters ambushed military forces east of the capital, killing at least 14 soldiers.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Doris Pilkington Garimara, Aboriginal Novelist, Dies at 76
item.description: Ms. Garimara was best known for her 1996 novel “Follow the Rabbit-Proof Fence,” which helped awaken Australians to the plight of the Aborigines and was later made into a film.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

item.title: U.S. Promotes Network to Foil Digital Spying
item.description: The State Department and other agencies are spending millions around the world to finance local systems, called mesh networks, as more secure alternatives to the Internet.
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL and JAMES GLANZ
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wireless routers attached to rooftops in Sayada form a local network that the developers say is more secure than the Internet.

item.title: John Shirley-Quirk, a Bass-Baritone and Specialist in Britten, Is Dead at 82
item.description: Mr. Shirley-Quirk was a British chemistry teacher who almost by accident became a renowned bass-baritone, making 30 appearances at the Met.
item.dc:creator: By MARGALIT FOX

item.title: Photos Link Masked Men in East Ukraine to Russia
item.description: Photos and descriptions suggest that many of the mysteriously well-armed gunmen in eastern Ukraine are Russian military and intelligence forces.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS, MICHAEL R. GORDON and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Aracataca Journal: Magic Ebbs From Colombian Town That Informed an Author’s Work
item.description: For Gabriel García Márquez, Aracataca served as the model for the fictitious town of Macondo in “One Hundred Years of Solitude.” For Cataqueros, it serves as home.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
